stream_context.summary: Kaze spends nearly the entire stream brainstorming and rough-designing Course 15, the “Space / Asteroid Arcade,” for Return to Yoshi’s Island.  He outlines high-level goals, sketches a hub-and-branch layout, selects several arcade-style sub-games, tests engine performance on N64 hardware, and discusses demo-release timing.

development_findings.summary: Course 15 will be a ‘Space Arcade’ built around a rocket-ship hub with three main paths and a lower ‘flipper pit’ that contains the red-coin star and serves as a movement shortcut.
development_findings.quote: If we do that, the flipper is entirely below the rest of the stage and it shoots you back up into the main area. I think I like that a lot.

development_findings.summary: Primary design pillars: Fun & freedom of movement, evoking awe through lights/visuals, and ‘certainty of goals’ so the player never wonders what to do despite a non-linear feel.
development_findings.quote: Most important order of business: do not ever have the player question what to do. The player always needs to know the way forward.

development_findings.summary: Low-gravity zones will be used; planetary gravity code already exists but will not be used here. Wing Cap and limited Cloud Caps will enable multiple movement solutions.
Kaze is considering up to six different act layouts that alter platform arrangements to build anticipation, but worries it may feel jarring or complicate Yoshi-coin placement.
Teleporters (possibly disguised as black holes) will shift Mario to distant set-pieces; Kaze prefers destinations to remain unknown to preserve a sense of discovery (‘edging’).
development_findings.quote: I don't want the player to know where it's taking them.

development_findings.summary: Mini-game stars chosen so far:  • Tetris-inspired survival climb  • Pac-Man maze with Chain Chomps  • Pinball-style flipper red-coin hunt  • ‘Skateball’ cannon shot challenge  • Hot Rope Jump (Mario Party) for a Yoshi coin.  Whack-a-mole and rhythm-game concepts were dropped.
Enemy roster ideas: newly designed Space Shy Guys (tall, possibly spinning attack) and recolored Space Skeeters; mechanical hazards will fill remaining roles.
Engine (new F3DEX3 based renderer) holds a solid 60 FPS on real N64 even with every enhancement enabled.
development_findings.quote: That's just how powerful the engine is.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to open-source the engine once the game is finished but not before, to avoid leaking content.
development_findings.quote: It will be open source once it's finished, so don't worry about that.

development_findings.summary: Planetary-gravity boss fight (Raphael Raven) is already implemented for Course 13; not reused here.
Current demo (Course 1) is ‘basically done’; tentative release shortly after Christmas to avoid heightened Nintendo takedown activity, likely early January on the ‘Kaze Clips’ channel.
development_findings.quote: I'm thinking I will release it shortly after Christmas… probably like first of next year or something.

context_findings.summary: Kaze consciously avoids launching fan content during the Christmas period because ‘Nintendo gets very angry’ then.
He conducts ‘thinking streams’ where he walks around the test map while talking through design problems.
context_findings.quote: What are you doing? I'm thinking!

context_findings.summary: Frustration with chat repeatedly requesting Roblox streams illustrates his focus and boundaries.
context_findings.quote: I did one Roblox stream… I'm not ever doing it again unless they pay me again.

context_findings.summary: He is German and occasionally references language/culture when chatting.

biobak.summary: Suggested relocating the flipper red-coin set below the main stage; Kaze adopted the idea as the key layout breakthrough.
Previously supplied many of the floating space assets (re-used from Scuttlebug hack) visible during brainstorming.

key_stories.title: Flipper-pit breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to make the level feel open yet goal-oriented.  Biobak suggested putting the pinball flipper platforms beneath the main arena; Kaze realized this simultaneously solves traversal freedom, red-coin placement, and visual spectacle.
key_stories.challenge: Level felt linearly chained and lacked an exciting red-coin concept.
key_stories.process: Brainstormed multiple hub-and-path variants; Biobak proposed flippers below; Kaze mentally prototyped interaction and performance.
key_stories.outcome: Design locked: an under-level flipper pit that both houses the red coins and catapults Mario back into the main routes.
key_stories.key_quote: If we put the flipper star entirely below the stage and it shoots you back up, that would connect everything so much.

key_stories.title: Timing the public demo
key_stories.summary: Kaze wants to publish the Course 1 demo soon but fears holiday DMCA waves.  He decides to wait until after Christmas and use a secondary channel.
key_stories.challenge: Risk of Nintendo issuing takedowns during the Christmas season.
key_stories.process: Assessed past patterns, weighed community eagerness versus legal risk.
key_stories.outcome: Plan to release demo in early January on Kaze Clips, not the main channel.
key_stories.key_quote: If you release stuff around Christmas, Nintendo gets very angry, so probably first of next year.

open_questions.context: Kaze floated having six distinct platform layouts per star but was unsure if it would feel jarring or complicate collectibles.
questions: Have you decided whether Course 15 will actually change per act?
What technical or design hurdles remain if you choose that path?

open_questions.context: He wants mystery destinations but also clear goals; no final decision on visual language.
questions: What visual cues will tell players a teleporter exists without revealing its destination?
How will you prevent players from feeling lost or punished for experimenting?

open_questions.context: Whack-a-mole and rhythm games were discarded; Tetris and Pac-Man were tentative.
questions: What criteria will lock in a mini-game concept?
